items.title: Queue tags overwrite event tags
items.body:
In code at https://github.com/librato/python-librato/blob/master/librato/queue.py#L66 the queue tags overwrite tags included with the individual measurement.

```
        if len(self.tags) > 0:
            query_props['tags'] = self.tags

        if 'tags' in query_props:
            self.add_tagged(name, value, **query_props)
```

It seams like this should be additive.

```
        if len(self.tags) > 0:
            tags = {}
            self.tags.update(tags)
            query_props.get('tags', {}).update(tags)
            query_props['tags'] = tags

        if 'tags' in query_props:
            self.add_tagged(name, value, **query_props)
```

This leads to the following code to miss behave:

```
>>> api = librato.connect("test", "test", tags={"env": "env"})
>>> queue = api.new_queue()
>>> queue.add('test.mtanski', 1, type="counter", tags=Stat('test', 'test', 'test').__dict__)
>>> pdb.run('queue.submit()')
> <string>(1)<module>()
(Pdb) b librato/__init__.py:169
Breakpoint 3 at /Users/mtanski/world/env/2u7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/librato/__init__.py:169
(Pdb) c
> /Users/mtanski/world/env/2u7/lib/python2.7/site-packages/librato/__init__.py(169)_make_request()
-> conn.request(method, uri, body=body, headers=headers)
(Pdb) p body
'{"measurements": [{"count": 1, "sum": 1, "name": "test.mtanski", "tags": {"env": "env"}}], "tags": {"env": "env"}}'
```

This took me far to long to figure out. We had tags setup per client (and queue) and individual queue.add measurements could have their own tags.

items.title: Python bug sending tags from queue
items.body:
It looks like there's a bug in the code at: https://github.com/librato/python-librato/blob/master/librato/queue.py#L139

```c['tags'] = dict(self.tags).update(c['tags'])```

__dict__.update function does not return anything (None) so it overwrites c['tags'] with None

items.title: Condition.from_dict omits tags
items.body: The constructor for `Condition.__init__`, `Condition.from_dict`, `Condition.get_payload` and possibly other methods need to accommodate tags.

items.title: `list_alerts` only returns 100 items
items.body:
This result is rather unexpected.

`list_alerts` should return as many alerts as asked for (default all) rather than arbitrarily stopping at 100.  Python provides generators to avoid having to store large lists in memory, so use them.

Sample implementation using a generator:

```
    # List alerts
    def list_alerts(self, active_only=True, **query_props):
        """List all alerts (default to active only)"""
        # Note: query_props may contain 'name' which would filter by name
        offset = query_props.get('offset', 0)
        while True:
            query_props['offset'] = offset
            resp = self._mexe("alerts", query_props=query_props)
            print("query: {}".format(resp.get('query')))

            alerts = self._parse(resp, "alerts", Alert)
            if active_only:
                for a in (a for a in alerts if a.active):
                    yield a
            else:
                for a in alerts:
                    yield a

            length = resp.get('query', {}).get('length')
            offset += length
            total = resp.get('query', {}).get('total', 0)
            if offset >= total or not length:
                break
```

items.title: `list_alerts` omits tags information from conditions
items.body: Tried with library and with cURL, so this is actually an underlying API bug.

items.body: This tests a Zapier integration.

items.title: Space.charts() throws exception if child Stream has color attribute set
items.body:
I'm setting up a script to create and update our spaces.  In order to update existing charts rather than deleting them and creating them fresh, I pull the existing charts using the `Space.charts()` method.  This worked until one of the charts had colors manually assigned to its Streams at which point I instead get an exception.

This occurred with version 1.0.2.

Sample REPL session to recreate:

```
>>> user = ...
>>> token = ...
>>> api = librato.connect(user, token)
>>> space = api.get_space(...)
>>> space.charts()
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/haydensikh/workspace/librato-spaces/.env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/librato/spaces.py", line 36, in charts
    self._charts = self.connection.list_charts_in_space(self)
  File "/Users/haydensikh/workspace/librato-spaces/.env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/librato/__init__.py", line 486, in list_charts_in_space
    charts = self._parse({"charts": resp}, "charts", Chart)
  File "/Users/haydensikh/workspace/librato-spaces/.env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/librato/__init__.py", line 201, in _parse
    return [cls.from_dict(self, m) for m in resp[name]]
  File "/Users/haydensikh/workspace/librato-spaces/.env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/librato/spaces.py", line 169, in from_dict
    related_space=data.get('related_space'))
  File "/Users/haydensikh/workspace/librato-spaces/.env/lib/python2.7/site-packages/librato/spaces.py", line 146, in __init__
    self.streams.append(Stream(**i))
TypeError: __init__() got an unexpected keyword argument 'color'
```

items.title: Add support for Spaces
items.body: https://www.librato.com/docs/api/#spaces

items.title: Service class, add title and type
items.body:
Currently Service class only retains the ID attribute, and discards 'title' and 'type'. This is mostly fine for defining alerts, but a bit annoying for introspection. For instance, if you want to pull a list of alerts to make sure they are all enabled for particular reporting service. 
Alternatively, being able to list the available services from /v1/services with full data would help, too.

Nov 23 13:29:16 jackdaw-prod-1 jackdaw-log:  WARN  [2015-11-23 19:29:15,562] com.librato.jackdaw.codec.InvalidParameter: <email redacted>[python-librato] Invalid key `type`

queue.py line 53 ==>nm['type'] = type

I think that this line should be removed

items.title: IOError raised in flush should display status code
items.body:
Hello,

I have sometime IOError that is raised when I flush. But the problem is that in the IOError object I just have a text that don't tell me what was the problem.

Here is the stacktrace I have:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/eee/anaconda/envs/eee/bin/zibrato-librato", line 9, in <module>
    load_entry_point('Zibrato==0.2.0', 'console_scripts', 'zibrato-librato')()
  File "/home/eee/anaconda/envs/eee/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zibrato/librato.py", line 106, in main
    l.flush()
  File "/home/eee/anaconda/envs/eee/lib/python2.7/site-packages/zibrato/librato.py", line 70, in flush
    raise IOError(r.text + ' ' + data)
IOError:  {"gauges": [{"name": "engine-time-engine_2", "value": 203.0, "source":     "dev:eee:1.internal", "measure_time": "1446481740"}, {"name": "engine-time-    default", "value": 122.0, "source": "dev:eee:1.internal", "measure_time":     "1446481800"}]}
```

The code in python-librato that raise this error is as follow:

```
  if r.status_code > 200 :
    raise IOError(r.text + ' ' + data)
  else:
    return r.status_code
```

As you can see, this does not tell me what was wrong. If I would have the status code it will help me to understand.

When creating a dashboard named "dash.board" the dot seems to be a problem:

``` python
    dashboard = self.api.create_dashboard(dashboard_name)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/librato/__init__.py", line 286, in create_dashboard

    raise exceptions.get(resp.status, resp_data)
BadRequest: [400] params: name: is invalid
```

But in the ui this name is valid - is there a way to escape it to allow chars like . and /? 
Thanks!

items.title: get does not accept composite metrics
items.body:
The (get method)[https://github.com/librato/python-librato/blob/master/librato/__init__.py#L187] does not accept the `compose` parameter, because it requires a `name` argument. 

I could provide a patch but the api doesn't specify what to expect in the response to a compose request so I don't know how to set up `Guage` or `Counter` object given such a response.

items.title: Auto-flush stats queue
items.body: Calling `Queue.add()` should occasionally flush its output to avoid accumulating too many chunks, perhaps when it reaches maximum POST size but at least in some tunable way to avoid having to keep track of that externally.

items.title: Unable to specify measure_time to librato.submit()
items.body:
I am having great success logging temperatures in real time, but I'd like to record some historical values by specifying a measure_time timestamp value when posting. 

Eg:

``` python
>>> import librato
>>> librato_api = librato.connect(librato_user, librato_auth)
>>> librato_api.submit("specificgravity", "1.046", description="specific gravity of wort in fermenter 1", source="fermenter1", measure_time="1396825200")
```

I've tried the timestamp as a string and an integer. Both times I get the following error:

``` python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/Users/rypalmer/.virtualenvs/spark-core/lib/python2.7/site-packages/librato/__init__.py", line 185, in submit
    self._mexe("metrics", method="POST", query_props=payload)
  File "/Users/rypalmer/.virtualenvs/spark-core/lib/python2.7/site-packages/librato/__init__.py", line 151, in _mexe
    resp_data, success, backoff = self._process_response(resp, backoff)
  File "/Users/rypalmer/.virtualenvs/spark-core/lib/python2.7/site-packages/librato/__init__.py", line 132, in _process_response
    raise exceptions.get(resp.status, resp_data)
librato.exceptions.BadRequest: [400] params: measure_time
```

Any idea where I'm going wrong here? Thanks!

Copyright

items.title: Auto-resubmit functionality from the ruby lib
items.body:
We would love to see some re-submit functionality similar to the ruby lib.

Basically if there are network outages or something similar, preventing values being submitted, it would be nice to see python-librato hold onto those values and resubmit them next time.... making the lib almost fire and forget from our perspective.

items.title: Release new version after taking care of open issues related to dashboard/instruments.
Explain new Instrument/Dashboard features in README.
regression testing
items.body:
The current integration testing (`make integration`) is not very useful since we perform requests very quickly and the backend doesn't have time to update. This causes some assertions to fail randomly.  

But I still want to be able to do some regression tests so I want to fix it. For the moment I will just run the requests sequentially and give some time to the backend to
update incoming resquests. Any other ideas to approach this are welcome.

items.title: Add testing for new instruments code.
Add testing for new dashboard code.
Bad status line error
items.body:
_This issues was reported by a user recently._

I have a problem with librato python bindings.

Code:

```
try: 
api.submit(metric, float(loadavg)/cnt, description="Varnish response time"); 
except BadStatusLine: 
print "Bad status line received"
```

After some time i get this error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last): 
File "libratoVarnish.py", line 26, in <module> 
api.submit(metric, float(loadavg)/cnt, description="Varnish response time"); 
File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/librato/__init__.py", line 182, in submit 
self._mexe("metrics", method="POST", query_props=payload) 
File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/librato/__init__.py", line 147, in _mexe 
resp = self._make_request(conn, path, headers, query_props, method) 
File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/librato/__init__.py", line 113, in _make_request 
conn.request(method, uri, body=body, headers=headers) 
File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/httplib.py", line 914, in request 
self._send_request(method, url, body, headers) 
File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/httplib.py", line 951, in _send_request 
self.endheaders() 
File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/httplib.py", line 908, in endheaders 
self._send_output() 
File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/httplib.py", line 780, in _send_output 
self.send(msg) 
File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/httplib.py", line 739, in send 
self.connect() 
File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/httplib.py", line 1112, in connect 
sock = socket.create_connection((self.host, self.port), self.timeout) 
File "/usr/lib64/python2.6/socket.py", line 553, in create_connection 
for res in getaddrinfo(host, port, 0, SOCK_STREAM): 
socket.gaierror: [Errno -2] Name or service not known
```

I tested on 8 diferrent servers.

items.title: New hosting mode in pypi
items.body:
As part of an ongoing attempt to improve the speed and reliability of PyPI
a change has been made to allow package authors to have more control over
their own packages.

This change allows you as an Owner or Maintainer of "librato-metrics" to pick
from 3 different hosting modes for your package, as well as control which
urls are exposed as installable targets for pip, easy_install, and zc.buildout.

You may find these options by going to https://pypi.python.org/, navigating to
your package, and clicking on the "urls" option.

items.title: can we get rid of the librato package in pypi?
items.body:
We have currently two librato packages in pypi: librato and librato-metrics. 
As far as I can tell librato is not being used. Can we get rid of it?

items.title: Latest pull request issues
items.body:
I sent this by email and I prefer to keep it here for future reference:

There are two things blocking us from releasing 0.4:
1. Travis doesn't seem to be able to create a python 3.3 env
2. jacobian wasn't sure if we allow non-ascii characters for the
   usernames. If we do, we will have to revisit this commit:
   https://github.com/jacobian/python-librato/commit/04073d1b5f50e4b7a9b2dd1b8cf058b965de7b00

for 1: jacobian added tox support for our tests (tox.ini in the repo).
Tox basically runs your tests against different python versions. I have
tried it out and all the test pass for 2.7, 3.2 and 3.3.
I propose we disable 3.3 testing in travis until they fixed at their end.

for 2: If you can confirm we do not allow non-ascii characters we will
be fine.

items.title: Don't swallow errors
items.body:
We shouldn't swallow errors up like this:
https://github.com/librato/python-librato/blob/master/librato/__init__.py#L111-L114
/cc @drio @jacobian

items.title: Use proper user agent
items.body: Use a proper user agent when making the http requests. Thanks @nextmat

items.title: README lists wrong install command
items.body:
The README lists the install command for the deprecated version of librato. Update to the correct package and remove the deprecated package from pypi.

/cc @nextmat @drio @ralphleon

items.title: refactor _mexe()
items.body: [_mexe()](https://github.com/librato/python-librato/blob/master/librato/__init__.py#L77-106)

items.title: Transparently retry 5xx errors, timeouts
items.body:
It would be good if the lib would auto-retry if it hits 503s (or really probably most 5xx errors), timeouts, etc, so that transient failures don't mean data loss. This is how we handle it on the ruby side in case it helps:

https://github.com/librato/librato-metrics/blob/master/lib/librato/metrics/middleware/retry.rb

items.title: Modify README to reflect lib changes.
Add clean feature to mocked API so we can have separate test methods
items.body:
Currently the mocking object for the APi is "started" prior to run the tests.
To keep a consistent state I have to run all the test from a
common method. Nothing wrong with that but we can do better. If I implement a
clean server method I can control the state of the server and run the unit
tests normally.

items.title: Fix copyright date in license files.
items.body: Should at least say 2013?

items.title: Use new '/metrics' route rather than deprecated '/gauges' '/counters'
Users have access to a CHANGELOG
items.body: Model after: https://github.com/librato/librato-metrics/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md

items.title: send pull request to django-app-metrics
items.body: Modify [django-app-metrics](https://github.com/frankwiles/django-app-metrics) so uses our python api for interacting with librato.

items.title: Send pull request to diamond with the handler using our package
items.body: [current handler code](https://github.com/BrightcoveOS/Diamond/blob/master/src/diamond/metric.py)

items.title: create_if_missing
items.body: Add new parameter (`create_if_missing`) to `send_gauge_value()` and `send_counter_value()`  so the user can decide if a metric should be automatically created or not.

items.title: Travis Support
items.body: When the tests are ready for automation, we can set up Travis integration. We have a private Travis account we can use for the time being, and switch it to the public Travis test-runner when we OSS this. /cc @nextmat
